Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 04:15PM EngTchr wrote: gjlanders--I had my fist treatment (TCH) today and it was fine and didn't hurt a bit.  I think I expected my veins to be burning up or something!  Watched TV a little, read, worked on a crossword puzzle and chatted a little.  It was 4 hours and 45 minutes from start to finish.  The nurse told me they run Herceptin very slowly the first time to check for any reaction.  It will take an hour less next time.   I would definitely to go Rome!  Welcome epohnyc--Jo, how many treatments will you be having?  What do DD ACT stand for?  I'm still learning all the various drug names. PAP, Patti, glad to hear your day 2 is going pretty well.  I think part of what's so hard about all this is knowing the huge list of potential side effects, and not knowing which ones we will have to deal with and when. Welcome, just-mary, wow there are getting to be a lot of us in June!  I'll bet those times are wrong.  I had three drugs today-Herceptin-1 1\2 hours, taxotere-1 hour, and carboplatin--1 hour.    Maybe when you asked him about injections he thought you were talking about Newlasta or something like that? TomnDi--I'll be thinking of you, your wife and family tomorrow.  I think everyone's reactions are different and it is difficult not knowing what to expect from day to day.  Maybe after this first one is over you'll have a better idea what to plan for for the subsequent treatments.  Everyone hang in there! Becky
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2009 10:20AM EngTchr wrote: Diane48, sounds like a tough first few days.  Hope the next few are better! Becky
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2009 09:33AM EngTchr wrote: Linda T, I completely agree with you about chemo being scarier than surgery.  I wasn't worried about it at all, but I find as I get closer to my first treatment next week the more I'm worrying and the less I'm sleeping.  I'm anxious to just get started and get it over with.  You and I have the same drugs--taxotere, carboplatin and herceptin.  I'm doing 6 treatments, 3 weeks apart, but also doing just herceptin on the two off weeks.  When the chemo is finished then I'm supposed to continue herceptin every three weeks until next June.  Also radiation.  Whew!  Glad that you seem to be doing pretty well with your first treatment.  I wish minimal side effects for everyone! Becky T

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2009 03:26PM EngTchr wrote: Hi everyone, PauldingMom, have you had surgery yet or does your surgeon want you to have chemo first?  There is so much information on the internet, including this site.  It can be pretty overwhelming, but I think it's very helpful.  When I was first diagnosed in April I spent hours on the computer and also checked out just about everything the public library had on breast cancer.  I feel like I had crash course!  Good luck with your appointment tomorrow and I hope you get some answers.  I took a good friend with me to my first appointment with the med onc to have an extra pair of ears.  She's a nurse and she said she learned a lot.  TCGGal, Laurie, I'll be thinking about you with your first tx tomorrow.  Mine is Wed.  Getting a little nervous.  I guess we'll all get through it.  I went wig shopping yesterday with a couple friends.  Made it all somehow a lot more real.  Becky

Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2009 05:59AM EngTchr wrote: Pam, I'll be thinking about you today.  The anxiety before the first tx is really something. I had an appointment with my onc yesterday and I want to share something he told me.  He said that the third week after the first tx can be a rough time for many women (I am two weeks out) because by then hair is usually gone.  Until that point the decision to tell someone that you're a cancer patient is yours alone and you can share it if you want to, but people can't tell by looking at you.  Once your hair is gone, though, if you aren't wearing a wig, everyone who sees you knows.  People will make stupid comments and sometimes treat you differently.  He just wanted to warn me that it can be an emotionally low time.  I thought that was good advice and I'll try to be ready for it.  I started losing my hair yesterday--day 15.  Getting it shaved off this afternoon! Becky

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 06:35AM EngTchr wrote: Pam, you might surprise yourself about the Neupogen shots.  My onc routinely prescribed 5 days of shots after each chemo (I had six txs.)  For the first two a really good friend of mine who is a nurse came over every afternoon and gave them to me.  They really don't hurt at all and the needle is very short and fine.  You're supposed to get them where there is a lot of fat (no problem for me!) and she did them in my stomach.  The third treatment she was going out of town on the third shot day.  I guess I could have asked someone else to do it, but I decided that I would give it a try.  She talked me through the one the second day--I was so hesitant to stick the needle in but she was so encouraging and said "Just do it!"  I did, and from then on, I gave the shots to myself.  I could always hear Wanda's voice in my head as I did them.  It is scary at first, but I'll bet you can do it, too. Hope you are able to get your treatment.  I felt the same way just wanting to get them finished. Becky
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Title: November Rads 2009 amlg1 EngTchr

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2009 01:16PM EngTchr wrote: Hi everyone, I belong here, too.  I had my ct simulation last week and have X-rays on Nov. 2 and first rads Nov 3.  When I originally met with the rad onc she told me I'd have 30 treatments.  The day I had the ct scan the techs said they blocked out my time slot for 36.  Hmmm.  I'll find out more about that next time I see the doctor. I had a lumpectomy on each breast--two completely different cancers.  One IDC, triple positive, and the other DCIS, triple negative.  I did 6 txs of taxotere, carboplatin, and herceptin, (last one was Sept. 30)  and will continue herceptin until next June.  They will radiate each side. I didn't have any kind of mold made.  Instead, I lay on a "breast board" with both arms over my head in little arm rests.  Got three tattoos. Nice to have others to compare notes with. Becky
Posts.Title: November Rads 2009 amlg1 EngTchr

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2009 03:31PM EngTchr wrote: Congrats on the last one, Blondie45!  What will you do next week with all your new free time?   You asked me yesterday whether I tan or burn in the sun.  I rarely burn, unless I overdo it early in the summer.  I'm not sure if radiation acts the same way as the sun as far as those who tan and those who burn.  My breasts haven't tanned much, but the skin under my armpits is very dark.  Doesn't hurt, but itches sometimes a little.  For the most part I've found rads to be pretty much SE free--much, much easier than chemo! Sparrow, good for you in conquering your fear!   This whole experience is toughening us up, isn't it! Becky

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2009 08:57PM EngTchr wrote: Deb, sorry you're having a bad day.  They have been drawing on me every day with sharpies before my treatments.  I get zapped on both sides and they line up the tattoo (just a tiny dot) between my breasts, then draw dotted lines to "mark the field" or something like that.  It comes off easily with baby oil.  They did warn me not to scrub the skin.  Now I'm finished with the regular treatments and getting the boosts.  For that, they drew an X on each one and put a clear sticker over it to show where to aim.  Took a little longer to set up the first day, but now it's really quick.  Just five to go--I am so ready to be finished! Becky
